date: stated on September 23, 2019 in a speech:
title: Dorbin is mostly on target with the prosecution about supporting the police to expand background investigations.
text: In remarks during a visit to the Chicago Democratic Hospital, Richard Dorbin said that President Donald Trump and the majority leader of the Senate Mitch McConnell were in the way of efforts in Capitol Hill to address armed violence despite widespread public support. Tramp and McConnell allegedly made strenuous efforts to expand background checks through the legislation of the two parties that cleared the home controlled by the Democrats more than 200 days ago. The current federal law requires background checks on licensed arms dealers but not on sales of arms by private vendors; the House of Representatives Bill requires background checks on all firearms purchases. Dorbin said, "The background checks make sense." "It appears that 90% of the police are so, 90% of the gun owners are so, and the overwhelming majority of the members of the National Gun Association are so. However, this President and the leader of the Senate refuse to act." The allegations of widespread support for background checks among the general public, along with statements consistent with what Dorbin said about the arms owners and members of the National Gun Association who also support them on a large scale, were previously reviewed by Polyte Facté. But his claim of support among law enforcement wasn't one we heard before, so we decided to check it out. A spokesman for the Durbin office referred to the results of a survey published by the Pew Research Centre in 2017, a generally reliable source of data. The experts we contacted told us that they were not aware of any recent surveys on the subject. This survey - conducted by the National Police Research Platform in Pio, a consortium of researchers based at the University of Illinois in Chicago - found that 88% of police support "makes private arms sales and sales at arms fairs subject to background checks." The margin of error for the question was plus or minus 2 percentage points, according to the Pio spokesman. As the detailed survey methodology section shows, online interviews were completed during the summer of 2016 by approximately 8,000 officers from 54 police and supervisory departments throughout the country. But the experts, including in Pyo, explained that there was only one warning worth remembering. The survey has left more small rural and municipal police forces throughout the country: it provides a nationally representative sample of officers working in districts employing at least 100 full-time officers, but does not include smaller departments. On June 8, 2016, Tammy Duckworth stated in a tweet that Mark Kirk called for a mass arrest of 18,000 Afro-Americans and that "it seems that he was fine with Trump's call for mass deportation. By Kevin Hoffmann on July 15, 2016, "while 88% seems to be a good estimate of this sampling framework, it may exclude a small part of state officers who have disproportionately more conservative views on arms control issues," said polling expert Stephen Smith, a professor of social and political science at the University of Washington, St. Louis. However, Smith indicated that a large majority of police officers throughout the country were likely to work in districts of the size listed. In fact, 63 per cent of all sworn officers work in departments with more than 100 officers, according to Pew. So the result still speaks of the majority. In order to gain some insight into this situation, we asked local law enforcement leaders why the police are likely to support the expansion of background checks. "Most of them want to protect the Constitution," said Frank Kaminski, Chief of Police Park Ridge, El. and former President of the Illinois Association of Chiefs of Police. "But they also see violence on the streets every day and realize that we must take logical measures to reduce it." "When we talk about violence, we talk about violence not only for citizens but also for officers," he added. While we were talking about legislation that would expand background investigations to all arms sales, Durbin said 90% of the police said such a policy. He was referring to a survey conducted by the Pew Research Centre in 2017, and asked the police in departments employing 100 or more officers whether they supported the request to check the background of private arms sales and sales at arms fairs. Eighty-eight percent answered that they did. However, it is important to note that the survey excluded staff in smaller and more rural jurisdictions who may not share the same views, and we have not been able to find any further recent surveys to address this issue. We're evaluating Durbin's claim mostly true. It is almost true that the statement is accurate but requires further clarification or information.
